parameters: \pop[2]We all sit around the kitchen table, much like we did when we were pregaming.
\pop[2]This part of the house became reserved for our more "special" plans.
\pop[2]And starting a campaign in Rebels and Revels was certainly special.
\pop[2]But not only that, everyone also stocked up on those gummies.
\pop[2]So we'd be role-playing under the influence. A pretty tall order.
\pop[2]These games usually had pretty complex systems to abide by.
\pop[2]But with Taylor as our GM, I'm sure he'd be pretty lax.
\pop[2]I feel like he'll make it fun, even if my character sheet looked like a spreadsheet...
\pop[2]If there's one thing I knew; it's that \c[14]nobody\c[0] liked working with spreadsheets.
\pop[2]I created my character, and named them after myself.
\pop[2]Delta, a sword-wielding warrior. But that's all I knew.
\pop[2]This world, and my place in it? I had no clue.
\pop[2]It's odd how that kind of mirrored how I felt in real life.
\pop[2]A game set in a completely different world, and I can still relate.
\pop[2]That's probably a good sign, though. I'd hate to play as someone I couldn't relate to.
\pop[4]Alright, well I don't want to get started \c[14]just\c[0] yet.
These things usually take a little while to kick in, you know?
Maybe we should just chat and relax until I'm ready to go.
I usually end up locked to the couch when I have these things.
If I start to doze off, I give you permission to write on my face.
\pop[3]Permission appreciated - and likely to be abused.
Kyron, you got any special requests? I'll draw on your behalf.
\pop[2]We all turn our heads toward the tablet on the table.
\pop[2]A slightly choppy video call with Kyron was already well in-progress.
\pop[2]It was too risky to have him over just yet, but he was happy to join remotely.
\pop[3]I'm pretty sure all of our minds went to the same place.
Let's keep it a secret. I wanna hear him scream when he looks in the mirror.
\pop[3]Pretty sure he does that every morning anyway.
\pop[4]Wow, rude! And I'm organizing this entire campaign for you.
Figured you could show me a bit more respect.
\pop[4]We will. Until you pass out, that is.
And if you feel bad, just remember that you did this to yourself.
\pop[2]Isaac waves a permanent marker in the air, as if it were a threatening gesture.
\pop[2]It's true, at least. Taylor is the one who came up with the wager.
\pop[2]As I feel the gummies kick in, I just hope that I don't pass out either.
Hopefully nobody's given you any trouble.
\pop[3]Oh, it's fine. Totally living a life of luxury.
I could use some better food, though.
The stuff on-board is super stale.
\pop[4]Oh, that's no good. But definitely expected.
It's actually part of why I chose that jet.
\pop[3]Wait. You chose the stale food on purpose? Heartless.
\pop[4]No, not the stale food. It was the rarely used jet.
Any other one, and you might've woken up in the air.
\pop[3]That sounds like it'd be fun, though.
\pop[4]It'd be a great way of getting caught, though.
\pop[3]Fair. I've just been craving some adventure, I guess.
\i[3]"This campaign should definitely scratch that itch."
\i[3]"This campaign should definitely scratch that itch."
\pop[4]I've never really played Rebels and Revels before, but I'm sure it will.
And if you really need to get out, we can always go back to the Triple R.
\pop[3]I'd rather come to Isaac's place, honestly.
Especially after hearing about The Quantum Leap.
But I'm hoping to know more soon.
\pop[4]Yeah. It's hard with all those \c[23]Argus\c[0] agents walking the streets.
It's just making tensions rise across the board. Not a help at all.
It's probably just an intimidation tactic.
\pop[4]That's a pretty bad way to de-escalate conflict, though.
The threat of retaliation, and even \c[14]further\c[0] escalation?
\pop[4]Yeah. If you're set up to fail, then there's no point in striking.
But it's really confusing in this situation. It's all been peaceful.
\pop[4]That's why a lot of people don't trust \c[23]Argus\c[0].
A lot of moves they make are equally good \c[14]and\c[0] bad.
But behind the shroud of mystery, most people focus on the bad.
\pop[4]Why hide something if there's nothing to hide, right?
I think \c[23]Argus\c[0]' silence is their greatest weakness.
Things could be \c[14]so\c[0] much better than they are.
\pop[3]Well, at least there's no agents around my plane.
But I agree. \c[23]Argus\c[0] needs to step up and say something.
All of this could be resolved with a single meeting.
\pop[3]Oh yeah. I heard that \c[10]Cipher\c[0] is calling for the leader of \c[23]Argus\c[0].
They've never appeared in public before, so nobody knows who they are.
But things are currently at a stalemate, so they might actually show up.
\pop[4]I can confirm that one, actually. \c[23]Argus\c[0] is kind of a mystery.
The farther you go up the chain of command, the more secretive things are.
I'd love to see the leader appear and negotiate, but I doubt it'll happen.
\pop[3]Well, if \c[23]Argus\c[0] does nothing, then we win anyway.
\c[10]Hermes\c[0] is gonna get phones to all those \c[10]zeros\c[0] regardless.
Nobody knows the true goals of \c[14]either\c[0] side, here.
But giving \c[23]Argus\c[0] time to act might end up backfiring.
\pop[4]Well, it's hard to get food in the city if you're a \c[10]zero\c[0].
\pop[4]That, and each second gives \c[23]Argus\c[0] more time to plan.
If they had agents good at acting, they could even infiltrate the \c[10]zeros\c[0].
They could sneak in, and tear it apart from the inside.
People say \c[23]Argus\c[0] is just "doing nothing", but I doubt it.
\pop[4]It's more like we can't \c[14]see\c[0] what they're doing.
But in their minds, I'm sure they've already planned it all.
Whatever happens in the next week or two is likely by their design.
\pop[4]So if they let \c[10]Cipher\c[0] get phones to the \c[10]zeros\c[0]?
Let them break the law, and then crack down.
But I think we'll be seeing a move from \c[23]Argus\c[0] first.
\pop[4]Well, if they don't do anything, \c[10]zeros\c[0] could start dying.
I can already see some of them on the streets, looking famished.
\c[23]Argus\c[0] could end this \c[14]immediately\c[0] by embracing the \c[10]zeros\c[0].
But the longer they don't, the worse everyone's condition is getting.
\pop[4]I can't imagine what it's like to be \c[10]Hermes\c[0] right now.
But if they're anything like me, they \c[14]know\c[0] where they messed up.
If \c[23]Argus\c[0] doesn't comply, they really \c[14]could\c[0] get phones to all the \c[10]zeros\c[0].
\pop[4]So this whole "you do it, or I will" thing, actually makes sense.
I just with that \c[10]Cipher\c[0] would strike while the iron is hot.
Waiting on \c[23]Argus\c[0] to act is just endangering lives.
\pop[2]It seems like the \c[10]zeros\c[0] would get phones regardless, though.
\pop[2]And those phones would either come from \c[10]Cipher\c[0], or \c[23]Argus\c[0].
\pop[2]However, the longer both sides wait to act? The more lives are at stake.
\pop[2]Not every \c[10]zero\c[0] had a friend like Isaac to get them into \c[23]The System\c[0].
\pop[2]If casualties become a factor, then my heart would shatter.
\pop[2]I even saw in a news poll that almost \c[14]everybody\c[0] wants to help the \c[10]zeros\c[0].
\pop[2]The longer \c[23]Argus\c[0] takes, the more public opinion shifts to support \c[10]Cipher\c[0].
\pop[2]And if a \c[10]zero\c[0] died on the streets of starvation?
\pop[2]Well, I imagine that shift would turn into more of a landslide.
\pop[2]But maybe that's part of \c[10]Cipher\c[0]'s game. Eroding \c[23]Argus\c[0]' public image.
\pop[2]Whoever this \c[10]Hermes\c[0] was, they're definitely a genius.
\pop[2]Holding the people that "govern the world" in a stalemate?
\pop[2]I just wish that the pieces on the board weren't actual lives.
\pop[4]Any chance we could get things moving?
I know the world is depressing, so that's why I wanted to do this.
The slumber party, and this new campaign? It's more like an escape.
\pop[2]This slumber party was supposed to be fun, not scary.
\pop[2]Try as we might, I don't think we could affect what was happening outside.
\pop[2]And so, we stay inside, in an attempt to drown out the external drama.
\pop[2]But as we're about to start our campaign, I can't help but stare at the table.
\pop[2]A board is placed down, with figurines in various spots, ready to move.
\pop[2]And Taylor, behind a cardboard partition, looks down at it.
\pop[2]One person, completely in charge, despite the will of the characters.
\pop[2]One person, guiding things down a specific path, no matter what happens.
\pop[2]In that moment, it was impossible to deny the parallels.
\pop[2]I can only hope that Taylor is a merciful GM.
\pop[2]And perhaps, that \c[23]Argus\c[0] is a merciful corporation...
